utterances: Well, there's three Western states that have been in play for quite a while.
Colorado, Nevada and New Mexico.
And Republicans have felt pretty good about them.
The Nevada is probably the only one that we continue to feel pretty good about...
Pretty good.
And maybe the caller know something I don't.
But we think McCain has held up pretty well there.
Colorado looks like a tough state.
I mean, I wouldn't say that it's non-competitive anymore, but Obama has held a lead outside the margin of error.
I believe - just barely outside the margin of error - for some time now.

And New Mexico remains competitive, too, but that was a state that went against Bush in 2000, swung back to Bush narrowly in 2004, you got a popular governor there putting himself on the line for Senator Obama.
Those three states are all important...
Ken had said the campaign looks like it's going to the Democrats.
Yeah.
That those three states are all in play and probably will remain in play, but Nevada is probably the most likely to remain Republican of the three.
Thanks very much for the call, Kitty.
My pleasure.
Thank you.
Bye-bye.
Here's some emails.
This is from Kim in Columbus, Ohio, where we're going to be next week.
I'm a Democrat in Ohio.
Every morning as I ride my stationary bike I watch an endless stream of political ads on the morning news.
Recently an outside group having to do with wild life preservation has been airing a hideous ad against Palin.
It shows live video people hunting wolves from airplanes.
I agree with the message but the ad turned my stomach.
And Ken, have the 527 groups - those - these are the outside groups who can operate under that part of the tax law, have they been playing a big part in the campaign this time?
Well, it's hard to say.
I mean, the poll - the ads have been up, and they've been reported by all the, you know, media markets and all that stuff, but I don't know if they have made that much of a difference.
Some of them are have been vicious like on both sides and liberties with the truth they've taken with both sides, as well.
But ultimately, I think, right now, people are just waiting for the debates.
The last debate is October 15th.
After October 15th, I suspect that if the 527 will have any effect, that's when you'll see it.
Not until then.
Anna Greenberg?
Well, I think that we see, compared to 2004, significantly less spending by 527s and outside groups, and there's a lot of reasons for that on the Democratic side.
Barack Obama sent pretty clear signals that he didn't want donors to write big checks to these outside groups.
But on the Republican side, we're also seeing significantly less money.
And a lot of the people who funded, say, swift vote and other groups, are opting out or spending much less.
You know, for a lot of reasons, either because Obama or because they think McCain is not going to win.
So there are ads up, like the defenders of Wildlife ad that the person who emailed talked about, but there's not the same kind of money behind them.
Vin, last time you were on - and Adam, by the way thanks, very much for the call.
Last time you were on, we were talking about the money difference and how it might not have been a such a big deal as we thought it might be.
Obviously, Obama can raise as much money as he would like, and John McCain accepted the public limitations earning three million dollars.
Is money beginning to be a factor now?
MR.
WEBER: I still don't think it's going to be as big a factor as we might have thought it was going to be maybe 60 days ago.
McCain is raising - has raised a lot of money.
The Republican National Committee continues to be an excellent choice of fundraising, and all of their one-off from spending it directly to the campaign.
They can spend the lot of money like a campaign would spend it.
So I think that they're doing well.
There's no question Obama continues to raise lot of money.
There's been no sign of a letup in his fundraising.
But you know, we're doing well.
Whatever Governor Palin's problems in the polling that Anna talked about, she continues to help raise money in both large and small contributions in substantial numbers.
Republican strategist, Vin Weber.
Also with us, Democratic pollster Anna Greenberg and Political Junkie Ken Rudin.
You're listening to Talk of the Nation from NPR News.
And we have a question from the audience here at the Newseum.
HAJIAR(ph) (Audience Member) Hi.
My name is Hajiar.
I'm from Berkley, California, and I have a question.

In light of the recent Republican demands and John McCain's step up his attacks against Barack Obama over the past couple of days, do you see both campaigns turning negative once again, or do you see John McCain understanding that the negative, dirty politics has backfired in a sense?
Well, I think both campaigns have been negative, and I think both campaigns will get more negative.

Yeah, I mean if you look at the advertising - and people who live in battleground states know this, know that both campaigns have been fairly negative - I think what Barack Obama can do because of money is actually have a couple tracks of media-ops.
So he's got very strong, positive ads straight to camera, and then a track of negative.
But it's never - the ads have been negative.
You know, really since before the conventions, yeah.
I, by the way, don't agree with the notion that negative equals dirty.
You can have a dirty campaign, there's no question about that, but negative ads can convey even more precise and accurate information than positive ads, and frequently do.
It is.
I like this is one.
But the two things that I think, you know, we might see happen, are, you know, I think McCain in some, you know, stepping up the attacks, as you say.
But one of things that came out of the debates, clearly he was seen as more negative.
It was, I don't - I think even though in some ways the debate was a draw, especially on economic issues, I think people came out feeling like McCain was pretty nasty.
The other piece is going back to these outside groups.
There's now push to air ads against Obama that mention, you know, Reverend Wright, that mention Bill Ayers, and you've seen those on the Internet and there's very small bias right now.
But I think that's where you'll see some of the nastiest, you know, come in.
I agree with that.

It's also interesting, though, the Democrats who say that McCain was too nasty during the debate are the same people who say that they want Barack Obama to be more negative in taking it to John McCain.
But the research that we did on the debate suggested that people liked it when Obama said, I agree John McCain, or they liked the civility.
Let's get another caller on the line.
Thanks very much for the question.
Let's go now Lindsay(ph), Lindsay with us from Denver in Colorado.
Hi.
I was calling a couple comments that were just made.
One, I thought that McCain was a little negative during the debate, and I certainly don't want Obama to get more negative.
In Colorado we're getting that ton of negative advertising, and a lot of that is in our Senate campaign as well.

But that's what I hear most people saying they're completely tired of, and the trickledown that I wonder is happening from that is here Colorado, and then my mom in Missouri, both a friend here and my mom had Obama signs stolen out of their yard.
And so I just wonder if some of that negativity...
I didn't do it.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Maybe Obama supporters who wanted to put it on their lawn.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Do what?
It might be from Obama supporters who want it for their lawn.
Well, we have a hard time getting them in Colorado but I wouldn't have if you made, even.

And - but I just wonder if that negativity in the big picture kind of trickles down to people, you know, doing things like that when part of what's amazing is that you can put any sign you want in your yard and you should be able to do that.
Yeah.

It does get - as it becomes more partisan as it gets down to the last couple of weeks - the last four weeks now of this campaign, four weeks and a little bit more, Ken, people do get very excited and do things that if they actually talked to the campaign they would tell them not to do.
And if Anna is talking about civility during the presidential race, the caller is exactly right.
In closely fought Senate races, below the radar, below the national radar, they have been uglier and uglier as they've been getting closer and closer.
Thanks very much for the call, Lindsay.
Thank you.
Bye-bye.
Bye-bye.
Here's an email.
This from Larry in Houston, Texas.
A couple of weeks ago I noticed I had not seen even one bumper sticker for McCain in Houston.
I see many Obama stickers in 2000 and 2004, there were many, many, many Bush-Cheney and then Bush '04 stickers.
Now, two weeks later, I still have not seen one McCain or McCain-Palin bumper sticker.

Either interest in Houston is low or the McCain campaign is not doing a good job, but nevertheless, I don't think Texas is in much doubt so maybe they're just not sending their bumper stickers to Houston.

Could I say one thing about - we're talking about the numbers, so if you go to the npr.org we have a map and a constantly updated electric map that right now, not including the tossup states, we have Barack Obama with 269 electoral votes.
And then we still have Nevada too close to call and Florida too close to call, New Hampshire too close to call.
Ohio is too close to call, but again, he's on the precipice of the magic 270.
Obviously, things could change, as has been said over and over again, for the next five weeks.
We're going to continue this conversation after a short break, and if you'd like to report in from your swing state, give us a call, 800-989-8255.
Email, talk@npr.org.
We also want to talk about some of the interesting Senate races around the country.
Email, talk@npr.org, if you've got a close Senate race in your neck of the woods.
I'm Neal Conan.
Stay with us.
It's the Talk of the Nation from NPR News.
(Soundbite of music)
Today on Talk of the Nation we're focused on swing states in this election, much like both of the candidates and with good reason.

No Republican has ever been elected president without winning the state of Ohio and Minnesota, which is in play this year, has voted Democratic in every presidential race since 1976, the longest such streak in the country.
Those facts courtesy of - who else?
Ken Rudin, NPR's political editor and our own political junkie.
We're joined here at the Newseum by Anna Greenberg, a Democratic pollster, and Vin Weber, a Republican strategist and a former Republican Congressman from the state of Minnesota.
And I wanted to read you this email that we got in about the Senate race there.

Any chance that Dean Barkley, the independent candidate who has 13 percent in the polls, could do a Jesse Ventura to Coleman and Franken, who have torn each other apart and made it a very ugly race there in Minnesota?
Well, that's a big question in that race because he's - Dean actually was appointed by Jesse Ventura and served in the Senate for a couple of months.
There wasn't anything happening so he didn't get a chance to make his mark, but he is a former senator.
He's at 13 percent.
Jesse Ventura never led, never came in second in any of the polls when he ran for governor that I saw, and I was watching pretty close.
And yet he won on Election Day, surging a lot at the end.
Unidentified Man #1: Coming up in here.
